Issues.Title: Optimize GroupBy.Sum and GroupBy.Mean for large DataFrames
Issues.Body:
I've analyzed the GroupBy.cs implementation and identified opportunities for performance improvements, including:
- Implement single-pass iteration over the group rows.
- Introduce typed accumulators for double and long to avoid boxing and improve numeric performance.
- Pre-allocate result columns (PrimitiveDataFrameColumn<T>) to reduce repeated resizing.
- Optimize delegates used during iteration for better performance.

I noticed issue #6824 tracks DataFrame performance improvements. Would performance enhancements for GroupBy operations be welcome as part of this effort?

I can provide benchmarks and a PR if there's interest.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Optimize GroupBy.Sum and GroupBy.Mean for large DataFrames" (#7554)

Issues.Title: Unable to load DLL 'FastTreeNative' when targeting `net472`
Issues.Body:
**System Information:**
 - OS & Version: [Windows 10 (x64)] 
 - ML.NET Version: [Microsoft.ML.FastTree v5.0.0]
 - .NET Version: [net472]

**Describe the bug**
The `FastTreeNative.dll` isn't being deployed to the output directory, causing a runtime exception when attempting to train a model.

> Unable to load DLL 'FastTreeNative'

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a project targeting the NET Framework (e.g. `net472`)
2. Include the ML.NET & FastTree packages (same behavior with either v4 or v5)
3. Create a simple training pipeline
4. Run the project and observe a runtime exception

**Expected behavior**
The appropriate `FastTreeNative.dll` is included in the output directory and no exception is thrown.

**Additional context**
The same code, targeting `net10.0`  deploys the `FastTreeNative.dll` in the `runtimes\win-x86\native` and `runtimes\win-x64\native` folders. If I manually copy the file from the `net10.0` build to the `bin\Debug` directory of the framework build, it works as expected.

Possibly related to #5308.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Unable to load DLL 'FastTreeNative' when targeting `net472`" (#7552)

Issues.Title: üß© Add pluggable SIMD-accelerated random generator (Mersenne Twister) and RNG abstraction for deterministic ML pipelines
Issues.Body:
### üìñ Overview
This PR introduces a new **pluggable random number generation (RNG) infrastructure** into ML.NET, replacing the previous `System.Random` dependency with a **deterministic, high-performance SIMD-accelerated Mersenne Twister (MT19937)** implementation.

The goal is to provide a **faster, deterministic, and cross-platform reproducible** RNG foundation for all stochastic algorithms (e.g., Random Forest, KMeans++, Isolation Forest, etc.) while maintaining full backward compatibility.

---

### üöÄ Key Changes
- **New interfaces:**
  - `IRandomSource` ‚Äî unified, injectable RNG abstraction  
  - `IRandomBulkSource` ‚Äî efficient vectorized bulk fill API  

- **New RNG backend:**
  - `MersenneTwister` ‚Äî pure C# MT19937 implementation  
  - `MersenneTwisterRandomSource` ‚Äî SIMD-optimized version using  
    - `System.Runtime.Intrinsics.X86.Avx2`  
    - `System.Runtime.Intrinsics.Arm.AdvSimd`  
    with automatic scalar fallback  

- **Integration:**
  - Updated `HostEnvironmentBase`, `ConsoleEnvironment`, `LocalEnvironment`, and `MLContext`  
  - New `RandomSource` property available on all `IHost` and `MLContext` instances  
  - Backward-compatible `Rand` property retained and wired through adapters  

- **Adapters for compatibility:**
  - `RandomSourceAdapter`  
  - `RandomFromRandomSource`  
  - `RandomShim`  

- **Testing and validation:**
  - Determinism tests for same-seed consistency  
  - Mixed consumption tests (`Rand` + `RandomSource`)  
  - Cross-platform reproducibility (Windows/macOS/ARM64)  
  - Performance microbenchmarks  

---

### ‚ö° Performance Impact
The new RNG is up to **5√ó faster** in real workloads.  
It eliminates per-call allocations and leverages vectorized bit-generation via SIMD instructions.

<details>
<summary>üìä Benchmark results (Isolation Forest prototype)</summary>

| Environment | Library | Mean Fit Time | Speedup |
|--------------|----------|---------------|----------|
| .NET 9 + ML.NET (SIMD MT19937) | C# | **0.21 s** | üü¢ **5√ó faster** |
| Python 3.11 + scikit-learn 1.5 | C/Python | 1.05 s | ‚Äî |

All benchmarks use identical seeds and datasets.  
Deterministic equivalence confirmed across runs and architectures.
</details>

---

### üî¨ Determinism & Reproducibility
- Bit-for-bit identical sequences across architectures (x86 ‚Üî ARM64)  
- Fallback to scalar path ensures deterministic output when SIMD unavailable  
- Each `IHost` and `MLContext` obtains an independent deterministic stream  
- Legacy `IHost.Rand` remains functional and maps to new RNG internally  

---

### üß† Motivation
This refactor lays the foundation for future high-performance stochastic algorithms in ML.NET.  
Reliable, cross-platform determinism and reproducible random streams are critical for modern ML workloads, testing, and research reproducibility.

It also unlocks future optimizations for:
- Tree-based ensembles (RandomForest, IsolationForest, GBDT)
- Sampling-based learners (KMeans++, NaiveBayes)
- Data shuffling, augmentation, and stochastic pipelines

---

### üîú Next Steps
In the **next PR**, I will introduce a **native Isolation Forest implementation** built entirely in C# using this RNG backend.

Preliminary testing shows the Isolation Forest algorithm using `MersenneTwisterRandomSource` performs **~5√ó faster** than scikit-learn‚Äôs Python version while producing numerically consistent anomaly scores.

This follow-up contribution will:
- Add the new `IsolationForestTrainer` to ML.NET  
- Include SHAP-style explainability support  
- Extend anomaly detection benchmarks and documentation

---

### ‚úÖ Checklist
- [x] Added RNG abstraction layer (`IRandomSource`, `IRandomBulkSource`)  
- [x] Implemented SIMD-accelerated Mersenne Twister (MT19937)  
- [x] Integrated with host environments and `MLContext`  
- [x] Ensured deterministic results across platforms  
- [x] Added backward-compatibility adapters (`Rand`, `RandomShim`, etc.)  
- [x] Added extensive unit tests  
- [x] Benchmarked vs scikit-learn  
- [ ] **Upcoming:** Isolation Forest algorithm using this RNG  

---

### üßæ References
- Matsumoto & Nishimura, *Mersenne Twister: A 623-dimensionally equidistributed uniform pseudorandom number generator*, ACM TOMS 1998  
- .NET Hardware Intrinsics Docs: <https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.runtime.intrinsics>  
- Internal discussions and performance notes related to RNG determinism in ML.NET #7502 

---

### üß© Example usage
```csharp
var mlContext = new MLContext(seed: 2024);
var rng = mlContext.RandomSource;

// deterministic sequence
uint a = rng.NextUInt();
uint b = rng.NextUInt();
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "üß© Add pluggable SIMD-accelerated random generator (Mersenne Twister) and RNG abstraction for deterministic ML pipelines" (#7525)

Issues.Title: Cross-Platform ML.NET Model Builder Extension for Visual Studio Code
Issues.Body:
## üöÄ Feature Proposal: Cross-Platform ML.NET Model Builder Extension for Visual Studio Code

### **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently, **ML.NET Model Builder** exists only as a Visual Studio for Windows component.  
Developers who use **VS Code, macOS, Linux**, or **GitHub Codespaces** have no accessible, GUI-based way to build or train ML.NET models.  
This leaves a large part of the .NET developer ecosystem ‚Äî especially those on non-Windows environments ‚Äî without first-class tooling for ML.NET.

---

### **Describe the solution you'd like**

Develop or officially support a **VS Code extension (‚ÄúML.NET Model Builder for VS Code‚Äù)** that provides a modern, lightweight, and cross-platform workflow powered by the **ML.NET CLI**.

#### üîß Core Capabilities
- Integration with `dotnet ml` CLI (ML.NET 3.x+).  
- Scenario wizard: classification, regression, recommendation, anomaly detection.  
- Dataset selection (CSV, TSV, Parquet).  
- Label & feature selection, ignore columns, training time configuration.  
- Live training progress and evaluation metrics in VS Code WebView.  
- Export models to ONNX or TorchSharp formats.  
- Optional GPU training (CUDA / OneAPI).  
- Integration with `.NET Interactive` notebooks for visualization.

#### üß† Developer Experience
- Works on **Windows, macOS, Linux, and Codespaces**.  
- Uses **modern VS Code APIs** (WebView2, ES modules).  
- Built with `esbuild` or `vite` for fast packaging.  
- Published to **Visual Studio Marketplace** and **OpenVSX**.  
- Potential starting point: [franzsilva/MLBuilderVSCode-Source](https://github.com/franzsilva/MLBuilderVSCode-Source) (early prototype).

---

### **Describe alternatives you've considered**
- Using ML.NET CLI directly (functional but non-visual).  
- Running Visual Studio Model Builder in Windows VMs or containers (heavy and impractical).  
- Using Jupyter notebooks with ML.NET (not native to .NET developers‚Äô workflow).

---

### **Additional context**

A **cross-platform Model Builder** aligns with the **.NET Everywhere** strategy and lowers the entry barrier for ML.NET adoption.  
It would make ML.NET approachable for students, researchers, and engineers working in containerized or non-Windows environments.  
It could also serve as a bridge to AutoML.NET and ONNX Runtime for inference workloads.

**Example roadmap:**
1. Migrate legacy codebase to modern VS Code API.  
2. Integrate ML.NET CLI 3.x+.  
3. Build a visual training wizard (dataset ‚Üí train ‚Üí evaluate ‚Üí export).  
4. Add ONNX / TorchSharp export & inference playground.  
5. Publish and maintain cross-platform builds.

---

### üè∑ Suggested Labels
`enhancement`, `cross-platform`, `ModelBuilder`, `AutoML.NET`, `VSCode`, `dotnet-tools`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Cross-Platform ML.NET Model Builder Extension for Visual Studio Code" (#7545)

We are excited to review your PR.

So we can do the best job, please check:

- [ ] There's a descriptive title that will make sense to other developers some time from now. 
- [ ] There's associated issues. All PR's should have issue(s) associated - unless a trivial self-evident change such as fixing a typo. You can use the format `Fixes #nnnn` in your description to cause GitHub to automatically close the issue(s) when your PR is merged.
- [ ] Your change description explains what the change does, why you chose your approach, and anything else that reviewers should know.
- [ ] You have included any necessary tests in the same PR.

Issues.Title: Add 16 KB page size support for Android native libraries
Issues.Body:
Starting November 2025, Google Play requires apps targeting Android 15+ to support 16 KB page sizes on 64-bit devices.

## Changes

Modified `src/Native/CMakeLists.txt` to add `-Wl,-z,max-page-size=16384` linker flag when `ANDROID` is set:

```cmake
# Support 16 KB page sizes for Android
if(ANDROID)
    set(CMAKE_SHARED_LINKER_FLAGS "${CMAKE_SHARED_LINKER_FLAGS} -Wl,-z,max-page-size=16384")
    set(CMAKE_MODULE_LINKER_FLAGS "${CMAKE_MODULE_LINKER_FLAGS} -Wl,-z,max-page-size=16384")
    set(CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS "${CMAKE_EXE_LINKER_FLAGS} -Wl,-z,max-page-size=16384")
endif()
```

This configures ELF segment alignment for 16 KB pages while remaining compatible with 4 KB page devices. Only applies to Android cross-compilation builds.

Issues.Title: Update Windows build instructions for CMake 4.0+ support, Spectre-mitigated libraries, and VS 2026
Issues.Body:
Users building on Windows with VS2019, VS2022, or VS2026 need updated documentation for proper build environment setup.

## Changes

**CMake version requirements:**
- Documented that CMake 4.0+ is now supported
- Specified minimum versions: CMake 3.14+ for VS2019, CMake 3.21+ for VS2022, CMake 4.2+ for VS2026

**Visual Studio installation section:**
- Generalized installation instructions to cover VS 2019, 2022, and 2026
- Added introductory text explaining similarities across versions
- Documented MSVC toolset version mapping (v142 for VS 2019, v143 for VS 2022, v145 for VS 2026)
- Changed section headers to "(Example)" format to indicate reference examples
- Added comprehensive VS2022 installation instructions with Spectre-mitigated libraries:
  - `MSVC v143 - VS 2022 C++ x64/x86 Spectre-mitigated libs (Latest)`
  - ARM/ARM64 variants for cross-compilation
- Updated Spectre-mitigated libraries note to be version-agnostic, covering all VS versions
- Documented location in VS Installer: Individual components ‚Üí Compilers, build tools, and runtimes

**Documentation structure improvements:**
- Reorganized VS installation sections with clear hierarchy showing examples for VS 2022 and VS 2019
- Updated all build instruction references to include VS 2019, 2022, and 2026
- Enhanced Known Issues section with CMake version compatibility information for all three VS versions

File: `docs/building/windows-instructions.md`

- Fixes dotnet/machinelearning#7467

Issues.Title: Use arcade script for installing MacOS dependencies
Issues.Body:
Building on MacOS was taking an additional 30+ minutes as it built dependencies like CMake, OpenSSL, etc from source.

Leverage the common script for installing dependencies used by runtime and other dotnet repos.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Use arcade script for installing MacOS dependencies" (#7533)

Issues.Title: [release/4.0] Improve unique directory generation for temp files
Issues.Body:
Backport of #7520 to release/4.0

/cc @ericstj

## Customer Impact
For each model opened ML.NET would leave behind a temp folder which would slowly accumulate in the temp directory.  It also had an algorithm for temp folder creation which would linearly degrade with each new folder.

## Testing
Tested fix that the folder is deleted and the creation algorithm does not degrade linearly if folders happen to be left behind because it uses GetTempFileName to produce significantly random folder name candidates.

## Risk
This fix doesn't clean up past folders, we should release-note that users may want to do this manually.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[release/4.0] Improve unique directory generation for temp files" (#7528)

Issues.Title: Remove baselines
Issues.Body:
Me & @rokonec came into conclusions that removing these should re-create BinSkim issues and not cause issues with other tooling. Baselines should contain entries for all active issues or issues already fixed since last baseline. Since we currently only have BinSkim entries in there we expect that after merging following will happen:
- automatic PR with baselines update
- BinSkim issues created

after this we should move permanent errors into suppression file and close out the issues
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove baselines" (#7526)
